awd_titl_txt: P2C2: Speleothem Records of Permafrost and Climate from an Ice-Proximal, Mid-Continent Cave
awd_abstract_narration:
The general aims of this project are to: 1) determine, using radiometric Uranium-Thorium dating of carbonate drip-features in the cave (speleothems), when past permafrost conditions occurred at Cave of the Mounds (CoM) in southern Wisconsin; and 2) develop a proxy record of hydroclimate conditions at CoM by measuring stable isotope ratios of oxygen in the speleothems. 

Specific project objectives are: 1) determining the timing of permafrost development at CoM over the past 250,000 years using Uranium-Thorium dating; 2) evaluating the hydroclimate conditions over this same interval using oxygen isotope chemistry; 3) examining the amplitude of high-frequency hydroclimate variability at CoM during ice-free and ice-proximal settings; and 4) measuring the duration and magnitude of hydroclimate changes across known abrupt climate transitions.

Permafrost presently covers approximately 25 percent of the land surface in the northern hemisphere and represents a significant sink of terrestrial organic carbon. Climate projections into the future indicate a significant increase in global average temperatures that will be amplified at high latitudes and could initiate a positive climate feedback through the release of additional carbon during permafrost thaw.  One way to constrain the sensitivity of permafrost to warming atmospheric temperatures is through the geologic record. Most paleo-permafrost reconstructions in North America are derived from geomorphic features, but these records do not provide continuous records of permafrost and/or climate conditions. This research project aims to reconstruct the chronology of paleo-permafrost and produce a record of hydroclimate over the past 250,000 years near the terminal margin of the LIS.  The CoM is in a unique position to provide a North American paleoenvironmental record that also measures the sensitivity of regional hydroclimate to glacial versus interglacial conditions.

The potential Broader Impacts include support for a female graduate student and two early career researchers, leveraging connections with the UW Geology Museum for outreach efforts, developing tutorials for sample preparation and imaging techniques (e.g. fluorescent imaging), and using the open-source, freeware, to collate imaging and geochemical data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Climate projections to the year 2100 indicate that global average temperatures will rise from 2 to 8C depending on future greenhouse gas emission scenarios (Collins et al., 2013). The modeled warming, however, is not spatially uniform; for instance, the Arctic and Antarctic are projected to warm 2-4 times the global average (Held and Soden, 2006; Collins et al., 2013). One way to constrain the sensitivity of environments to changing climates is through the geologic record. Earth's climate evolution of the last several hundred thousand years has been dominated by glacial cycles. These cooling and warming phases provide a natural experiment for testing the sensitivity of climate change to both long-term (1000s years) and short-term (10s years) climate changes.

As part of this project, we have established how climate changed in the mid-continent of North America during several key geologic intervals in the past from cave deposits (speleothems) at Cave of the Mounds (CoM). The cave is situated on the flank of the Blue Mounds in the unglaciated portion ('Driftless Area') of southwestern Wisconsin (U.S.A.) and was once about 25 miles from the last great ice sheet that covered most of Wisconsin 20,000 years ago. Speleothems record past climate in the geochemistry of the calcium carbonate that accumulates layer-by-layer to form stalagmites, stalactites, and flow stones (see Figure 1). To do this, we applied a combination of specialized imaging techniques and high resolution mass spectrometry methods on a set of speleothem samples from CoM to reconstruct past climate changes in the mid-continent of North America for portions of the last 250,000 years. As part of this study we developed a chronology of past climate changes at CoM that constrained permafrost conditions over the past 250,000 years (Batchelor et al. 2019). We applied our specialized imaging techniques and high resolution mass spectrometry methods to produce sub-millennial climate records representative of mid-continental North America for multiple portions of the late Pleistocene (Batchelor, 2022; Batchelor et al. 2022; Batchelor et al. in revision;) that better constrain climate sensitivity to changing boundary conditions on decadal to millennial timescales in this region. Results from this work provide unprecedented constraints on midcontinental hydroclimate variability for portions of the last 250,000 years. Outcomes from this study have been disseminated to broader audiences through a day long exhibit at the University of Wisconsin Geologic Museum, several science-based outreach events at local elementary schools, and the scientific results have been incorporated into outreach material and displays as part of the Cave of the Mounds tours which host more than 100,000 visitors a year.
